Cheers rang through the Labour camp in North Tyneside after Norma Redfearn won a second term as mayor. 
Ms Redfearn was re-elected to the position with 56% of the vote, making her the first mayor in the borough to win back-to-back elections. 
She received 29,655 votes in total, while Conservative candidate Stewart Hay had 16,164 (30.5%). 
Liberal Democrat John Appleby was third with 3,537 (6.7%) and UKIP’s Stuart Houghton was not far behind with 3,248 (6.1%). 
The result, which was announced at the Parks Leisure Centre in North Shields on Friday afternoon, delighted Labour supporters who clapped and cheered as the figures were revealed. 
Ms Redfearn then took to the podium and thanked residents for their backing. Read More Who is Norma Redfearn? What you need to know about the North Tyneside mayoral election candidate 
She added: “I would like to take this opportunity to thank the residents of North Tyneside for re-electing me for a second term. 
“I think this reflects the good progress we have made over the last four years, and my commitment to delivering on our priorities over the coming years. 
“During this time, I will continue to be a listening mayor for everyone in North Tyneside.” 
Ms Redfearn said it was “back to work” for her and she planned to carry on with regeneration schemes that have already started as well as looking into other areas that need improvement. 
“I’m delighted to have won and to get such a majority,” she added. “This means people actually believe in what we are doing and means I can continue this journey we are on in North Tyneside, to make it the best place to live, work and visit - a place to be proud of.” 
Conservative candidate Stewart Hay said he was disappointed not to have won but was pleased with the efforts his campaign team had made. 
He added: “We engaged with the public and got a lot of positive feedback while we were campaigning. Read More Local election results 2017 LIVE: Durham and North Tyneside counts after Tory victories in Northumberland 
“On the doorstep, we found that every other voter was talking about Brexit. This clearly will be an issue at the General Election.” 
Overall turnout was 34.25% and the total number of votes was 52,921 - around 2% more than the previous mayoral election in 2013.
